title: 106_s940
content: The Act states that any amendments refer to title 38, United States Code. The Act is titled "Department of Veterans Affairs Employment Reduction Assistance Act of 1999". It also includes definitions. The Act defines "Department" as the Department of Veterans Affairs and "Employee" as an employee of the Department with at least 3 years of continuous service, excluding certain categories of employees. The Act excludes certain categories of employees from receiving voluntary separation incentive payments, including those under specific retirement systems, with notice of involuntary separation, who have previously received such payments, on transfer with reemployment rights, or who have received recruitment or relocation bonuses in the past 24 months. The Act excludes certain employees from receiving separation incentive payments, including those under specific retirement systems, with notice of involuntary separation, who have previously received such payments, on transfer with reemployment rights, or who have received recruitment or relocation bonuses in the past 24 months. Additionally, any employee who received a retention allowance or bonus in the twelve-month period before separation is also excluded. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. SEC. 3. DEPARTMENT PLANS; APPROVAL. Before implementing voluntary separation incentive payments, the Secretary must submit a strategic plan to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The plan should outline the positions and functions to be reduced or eliminated within the Department, based on various factors such as organizational unit, geographic location, occupational category, and grade level. The Secretary must submit a strategic plan to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget outlining reductions in positions and functions within the Department. The plan should detail how these reductions will enhance operating efficiency or align with budget and staffing resources. The Director will approve or modify the plan, including the time period for incentive payments and the number and amounts of payments. SEC. 4. VOLUNTARY SEPARATION INCENTIVE PAYMENTS. The Secretary may provide voluntary separation incentive payments to reduce positions and functions as per the strategic plan. Employees must voluntarily retire or resign to be eligible for the payment, which is a lump sum equal to the amount entitled under section 5595(c) of the Act. The Secretary may provide voluntary separation incentive payments to eligible employees, which can be a lump sum payment equal to the amount entitled under section 5595(c) of the Act, or up to $25,000 as determined by the Secretary. These payments are not considered for other government benefits or severance pay calculations and are funded from the employee's basic pay appropriations. SEC. 5. EFFECT OF SUBSEQUENT EMPLOYMENT WITH THE GOVERNMENT. An individual who received a voluntary separation incentive payment must repay the full amount if they work for the Government of the United States within 5 years. The repayment may be waived if the individual has unique abilities and is the only qualified applicant for the position. An individual who received a voluntary separation incentive payment must repay the full amount if they work for the Government of the United States within 5 years. Repayment may be waived if the individual has unique abilities and is the only qualified applicant for the position in the legislative or judicial branch. Employment without compensation or through a personal services contract with any agency of the United States Government is included for repayment of a voluntary separation incentive payment within 5 years. Repayment may be waived for individuals with unique abilities who are the sole qualified applicant in the legislative or judicial branch. The Department must remit 15 percent of the final basic pay of employees who received a voluntary separation incentive to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. Final basic pay is calculated based on the employee's final rate of basic pay for a year of service. SEC. 7. REDUCTION OF AGENCY EMPLOYMENT LEVELS. The Department's full-time equivalent employment is reduced by one for each employee who receives a voluntary separation incentive payment. The President will monitor and enforce compliance with this requirement. Waivers may be granted in cases of war, national emergency, or extraordinary emergencies. The Department may grant waivers in cases of war, national emergency, or extraordinary emergencies. SEC. 8. CONTINUED HEALTH INSURANCE COVERAGE. Section 8905a(d)(4) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for involuntary separation from the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Defense. The paragraph applies to individuals with continued coverage based on separation dates before October 1, 2004. The paragraph specifies that individuals with continued coverage based on separation dates before October 1, 2004, will be affected by the provisions for involuntary separation from the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Defense. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management may prescribe regulations to administer the Act. No voluntary separation incentive can be paid after September 30, 2004. The Act supplements other authority of the Secretary and takes effect upon enactment.
